summary: This document is a collection of email correspondence primarily concerning the detention, attempted suicide, and death of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It includes a preservation request from Epstein's family attorney, internal BOP communications about the July 23 incident, and media inquiries from a journalist. The emails reveal details about Epstein's cellmate, his medical and psychological assessments, and the immediate aftermath of his death. This document is a series of email correspondences from July-August 2019 between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) officials and a journalist regarding Jeffrey Epstein's status at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details his removal from suicide watch to psychological observation, an incident of self-mutilation with a makeshift noose, and discussions about his cellmate assignment. It also includes a journalist's inquiries following Epstein's death. This document is a series of email correspondences from July-August 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration at MCC New York. It details his initial suicide attempt on July 23, his subsequent removal from suicide watch, his psychological status, housing assignments, and official communications with the press following his death. It reveals internal discussions about his cellmate situation and protocol failures. This document is a collection of email correspondence from July to October 2019, primarily between Bureau of Prisons (BOP) officials, law enforcement, and journalists regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration, suicide attempts, and eventual death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details his status changes (suicide watch, psychological observation), the July 23, 2019 incident where he was found with a noose, and the official press release announcing his death by apparent suicide on August 10, 2019. This document is a collection of email correspondence from July and August 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details an incident on July 23 where Epstein was found with neck injuries and placed on suicide watch, his subsequent removal to psychological observation, and the official press release announcing his death by apparent suicide on August 10. The emails include internal BOP communications and inquiries from journalists. This document is a series of email exchanges between Bureau of Prisons officials at MCC New York and the Regional Director concerning Jeffrey Epstein's status following an incident where he was found with a makeshift noose. It details his removal from suicide watch to psychological observation, discussions about his mental state, a pending incident report for self-mutilation, and plans for his housing, including a potential cellmate who was a high-profile inmate. This document contains Bureau of Prisons internal emails, an incident report (Form 583), and staff memoranda regarding Jeffrey Epstein's reported suicide attempt in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York on July 23, 2019. It details the initial response, Epstein's medical status, his allegations against his cellmate, and subsequent administrative updates, including his removal from suicide watch. This document contains Bureau of Prisons records from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York detailing the incident on July 23, 2019, where inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a rope around his neck. It includes staff shift logs, a clinical encounter report, photo sheets, an administrative detention order, an incident report, and internal email correspondence regarding the event and his subsequent placement on suicide watch. This document contains internal email correspondence from July-August 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's condition and status at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York following an incident on July 23, 2019, where he was found with injuries to his neck. It includes updates on his medical and psychological assessments, discussions about his housing and cellmate assignments, and a reporter's inquiry following his death. This document is a series of email exchanges from July-August 2019 among Bureau of Prisons (BOP) staff regarding an incident involving Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details the discovery of Epstein with neck injuries, his placement on suicide watch, medical and psychological assessments, and internal discussions about his status and cellmate. It also includes a later email about his death and a media inquiry. This document contains internal Bureau of Prisons email correspondence regarding the status, medical and psychological assessments, and housing plans for inmate Jeffrey Epstein following an incident in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on July 23, 2019, where he was found with marks on his neck. It includes discussions about his placement, a potential cellmate, and a later complaint from his attorney about conditions.

events.title: Epstein Found Injured in Cell
events.description: At 1:27 a.m., staff found inmate Jeffrey Epstein (No. 76318-054) lying on the floor of his SHU cell in a fetal position with red marks/a 'makeshift noose' around his neck. He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the MCC New York. The events of the evening of August 9 through the morning of August 10 are under investigation.

events.title: Preservation Request Filed
events.description: Attorney Martin G. Weinberg, on behalf of Epstein's family, sends a comprehensive request to the MCC to preserve all evidence and records related to Epstein's detention and death.

events.title: Epstein Found with Makeshift Noose
events.description: At 0127 hours, inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell in a fetal position with a makeshift noose around his neck. He was escorted to medical, initially placed on suicide watch, and later downgraded to psychological observation.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Inmate Epstein was removed from Suicide Watch and stepped down to Psychological Observation status. He was escorted for a follow-up assessment and to meet with his attorney.

events.title: Daily Psychological Assessments
events.description: Epstein was assessed daily by psychologist services and remained on Psychological Observation status over the weekend of July 26-28, with reassessment scheduled for Monday.

events.title: Pending Incident Report for Self-Mutilation
events.description: Epstein faced a pending incident report for a Code 228 violation (Tattooing or Self-Mutilation) related to the noose incident. A Unit Discipline Committee (UDC) hearing was pending.

events.title: Journalist Inquiries About Epstein's Death
events.description: Journalist Pervaiz Shallwani contacted BOP officials to confirm reports that Jeffrey Epstein had committed suicide at MCC Manhattan and asked detailed questions about the circumstances.

events.title: Epstein's First Suicide Attempt
events.description: At 1:27 a.m., staff found Jeffrey Epstein in his SHU cell lying on the floor in a fetal position with a makeshift noose around his neck. He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Removal from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was removed from suicide watch and stepped down to 'Psychological Observation' status. He was assessed and later met with his attorney.

events.title: Report of Epstein's Death
events.description: Journalist Pervaiz Shallwani emails the BOP asking for confirmation of reports that Jeffrey Epstein 'commuted suicide' at MCC.

events.title: Incident Report for Self-Mutilation
events.description: Epstein was pending a 'Code 228' incident report for Tattooing or Self-Mutilation related to the noose incident, leading to a pending UDC hearing.

events.title: Epstein Found with Noose in Cell
events.description: At 1:27 a.m., staff found Jeffrey Epstein in his SHU cell in a fetal position with a noose around his neck. He was escorted to medical, assessed, and placed on suicide watch, later downgraded to suicide observation. His cellmate reported being threatened.

events.title: Epstein Found Dead in Cell
events.description: At approximately 6:30 a.m., Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his SHU cell at MCC New York from an apparent suicide. Life-saving measures were initiated, and he was transported to a local hospital where he was pronounced dead.

events.title: Epstein Arrives at MCC New York
events.description: Epstein arrived at the Metropolitan Correctional Center under pretrial status after being indicted for sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy.

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Injuries
events.description: At 1:27 a.m., staff responded to Epstein's cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). He was found on the floor in a fetal position with red marks on his neck. He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Housing and Observation Reviews
events.description: Internal BOP emails discuss plans to move Epstein to general population, review potential cellmates, and note he will remain on Psychological Observation over the weekend of July 26-28.

events.title: Epstein's Reported Suicide Attempt at MCC
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with an orange cloth/noose around his neck, appearing unresponsive. Staff responded, removed him, and placed him on suicide watch. He later alleged his cellmate tried to kill him.

events.title: Incident Report (Form 583) Circulated
events.description: A Special Investigative Technician named Mike forwarded the completed Form 583 report documenting the July 23 incident to a superior.

events.title: Epstein Found with Rope in Cell
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, correctional staff found inmate Jeffrey Epstein in his cell (SHU Z05-Cell 124) lying on the floor in a fetal position with an orange homemade rope around his neck. He was unresponsive but breathing.

events.title: Medical Assessment
events.description: At 6:30 AM, Epstein was assessed by MLP Joaquin, Y. He was ambulatory, oriented, and smiling. He had a circular line of erythema (redness) around his neck but denied pain or knowledge of how it happened. He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Incident Photography
events.description: A Lieutenant took photographs of the incident scene in the Special Housing Unit at 1:45 AM and of the cellmate at 2:25 AM, documenting a 'Possible Suicide Attempt'.

events.title: Administrative Detention Order
events.description: An order was issued to place Epstein in Administrative Detention, citing a pending classification and that his presence in general population posed a serious threat.

events.title: USMS Notification
events.description: The U.S. Marshals Service relayed a report from the BOP stating Epstein was found with a noose and that his cellmate had reportedly threatened to kill him.

events.title: Medical and Psychological Assessment
events.description: Epstein was medically assessed at 6:30 a.m. and psychologically evaluated at 9:10 a.m. He was found ambulatory and oriented but had a circular line of erythema on his neck. He was kept on suicide watch.

events.title: Downgraded to Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was removed from suicide watch and stepped down to psychological observation. He had a pending incident report for self-mutilation (Code 228).

events.title: Update on Epstein's Condition
events.description: Epstein reported memory impairment from sleep apnea, requested to stay in a 'safe' area, but was scheduled to return to SHU with a cellmate after receiving his CPAP machine.

events.title: Reporter Inquiry on Epstein's Death
events.description: Reporter Alex Dobuzinskis emailed seeking confirmation that Jeffrey Epstein died of suicide at the facility, asking for time and method.

events.title: Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was removed from suicide watch, stepped down to psychological observation, and escorted for a follow-up assessment and a meeting with his attorney.

events.title: News of Epstein's Death
events.description: An email forwards a New York Post article with the headline 'Convicted pedophile Jeffrey Epstein dead'.

events.title: Epstein Found Injured in SHU Cell
events.description: At 1:27 a.m., staff responded to Epstein's SHU cell and found him lying on the floor in a fetal position with red marks on his neck. He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Medical and Psychological Assessments
events.description: Epstein was medically assessed at 6:30 a.m. (noting erythema on neck/knee) and psychologically evaluated at 9:10 a.m., resulting in continued suicide watch.

events.title: Status Change to Psychological Observation
events.description: Epstein was removed from Suicide Watch and stepped down to Psychological Observation status. Plans were made to return him to SHU with a cellmate.

events.title: Complaints of Numbness and Toilet Noise
events.description: Epstein complained of numbness in his right arm and neck, and that a running toilet in his cell prevented sleep. He was taken off Psych Observation.

events.title: Attorney Complaint About Conditions
events.description: Attorney Michael Miller emailed the BOP alleging Epstein was not being provided water in attorney visiting offices and had follow-up questions about conditions.
